title: Overview
text:
Value ≥ Complexity Added?
Added value is significant, but tooling, maintenance, etc. much more complex than the core functionality.

quality_payment()
quality_eligibility()
open_payments()
utilization()
prescribers()

title: Overview
text:
Questioning: Out of Scope
Surplus to requirements, e.g. historical provider data (either kept current or no longer updated), an applicable area of interest large enough to be moved into its own package, or tangential functionality:

outpatient()
beneficiaries()

title: 1  API FAQ
text:
1.1 Data Catalog
Working through the new (October 2024 - Version 1.6) API FAQ for data.CMS.gov, extracting the relevant information
The data.json file is an Open Data catalog containing the datasets available on our site. As new data is added, it is automatically updated to the data.json.
data_json_meta <- read_json_arrow(
  file = "https://data.cms.gov/data.json",
  col_select = c("dataset"),
    as_data_frame = TRUE) |> 
  to_duckdb()

data_json_meta |> 
  glimpse()

Rows: ??
Columns: 1
Database: DuckDB v1.1.3 [Andrew@Windows 10 x64:R 4.4.2/:memory:]
$ dataset <list> [<data.frame[138 x 22]>]
In the data.json, there is an array called dataset. You can search through this array using the title of your dataset, such as "Payroll Based Journal Daily Nurse Staffing":
data_json_meta |> 
  pull(dataset) |> 
  pluck(1) |> 
  filter(grepl("Payroll Based Journal Daily Nurse Staffing", title)) |> 
  glimpse()

Rows: 1
Columns: 22
$ `@type`            <chr> "dcat:Dataset"
$ accessLevel        <chr> "public"
$ accrualPeriodicity <chr> "R/P3M"
$ bureauCode         <list> "009:38"
$ contactPoint       <df[,3]> <data.frame[1 x 3]>
$ describedBy        <chr> "https://data.cms.gov/resources/payroll-based-journ…
$ dataQuality        <lgl> TRUE
$ description        <chr> "The Payroll Based Journal (PBJ) Nurse Staffing and…
$ distribution       <list> [<data.frame[61 x 10]>]
$ identifier         <chr> "https://data.cms.gov/data-api/v1/dataset/7e0d53ba-…
$ keyword            <list> <"Medicare", "Original Medicare", "Hospitals & Fac…
$ landingPage        <chr> "https://data.cms.gov/quality-of-care/payroll-ba…
$ language           <list> "en-US"
$ license            <chr> "https://www.usa.gov/government-works"
$ modified           <dttm> 2024-10-31
$ programCode        <list> "009:000"
$ publisher          <df[,2]> <data.frame[1 x 2]>
$ references         <list> "https://data.cms.gov/resources/payroll-based-journ…
$ temporal           <chr> "2017-01-01/2024-06-30"
$ theme              <list> "Medicare"
$ title              <chr> "Payroll Based Journal Daily Nurse Staffing"
$ describedByType    <chr> NA
Inside of the dataset, there is an array called distribution which will contain all the versions of the data in all available formats for each version.
data_json_meta |> 
  pull(dataset) |> 
  pluck(1) |> 
  slice(1) |> 
  select(distribution) |> 
  unnest(distribution) |> 
  glimpse()

Rows: 25
Columns: 10
$ `@type`      <chr> "dcat:Distribution", "dcat:Distribution", "dcat:Distribut…
$ format       <chr> "API", NA, "API", NA, "API", NA, "API", NA, "API", NA, "A…
$ accessURL    <chr> "https://data.cms.gov/data-api/v1/dataset/9767cb68-8ea9-4…
$ resourcesAPI <chr> "https://data.cms.gov/data-api/v1/dataset-resources/9767c…
$ description  <chr> "latest", NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA, NA,…
$ title        <chr> "Accountable Care Organization Participants : 2024-01-24"…
$ modified     <dttm> 2024-01-29, 2024-01-29, 2024-01-29, 2023-03-06, 2023-03-…
$ temporal     <chr> "2024-01-01/2024-12-31", "2024-01-01/2024-12-31", "2024-0…
$ downloadURL  <chr> NA, "https://data.cms.gov/sites/default/files/2024-01/afc…
$ mediaType    <chr> NA, "text/csv", NA, "text/csv", NA, "text/csv", NA, "appl…
In this array there are a few different types of entries:
The first entry (with a description of ‘latest’) will provide a URL that will always point to the latest data, even as new versions are published.
The remaining entries will provide references to the data at fixed points in time, listed in descending order by date.
For example, the URL in the following example will always point to the Payroll Based Journal Daily Nurse Staffing data from Q2 2021:
resp_nurse <- request("https://data.cms.gov/data-api/v1/dataset/d10d792e-ea6e-4145-8512-34efbc1be04b/data") |> 
  req_perform(verbosity = 3) |> 
  resp_body_json(simplifyVector = TRUE)

Rows: 1
Columns: 33
$ PROVNUM          <chr> "015010"
$ PROVNAME         <chr> "COOSA VALLEY HEALTHCARE CENTER"
$ CITY             <chr> "SYLACAUGA"
$ STATE            <chr> "AL"
$ COUNTY_NAME      <chr> "Talladega"
$ COUNTY_FIPS      <chr> "121"
$ CY_Qtr           <chr> "2021Q2"
$ WorkDate         <chr> "20210401"
$ MDScensus        <chr> "70"
$ Hrs_RNDON        <chr> "8"
$ Hrs_RNDON_emp    <chr> "8"
$ Hrs_RNDON_ctr    <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_RNadmin      <chr> "48.25"
$ Hrs_RNadmin_emp  <chr> "48.25"
$ Hrs_RNadmin_ctr  <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_RN           <chr> "32"
$ Hrs_RN_emp       <chr> "32"
$ Hrs_RN_ctr       <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_LPNadmin     <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_LPNadmin_emp <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_LPNadmin_ctr <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_LPN          <chr> "63.25"
$ Hrs_LPN_emp      <chr> "63.25"
$ Hrs_LPN_ctr      <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_CNA          <chr> "189.5"
$ Hrs_CNA_emp      <chr> "189.5"
$ Hrs_CNA_ctr      <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_NAtrn        <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_NAtrn_emp    <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_NAtrn_ctr    <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_MedAide      <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_MedAide_emp  <chr> "0"
$ Hrs_MedAide_ctr  <chr> "0"
Some datasets will have multiple historical versions available and some will only have the most recent data available.
The data with mediaType of “text/csv” is downloadable as a CSV file and data with mediaType of “application/zip” is downloadable as a ZIP file.
The data with a format of “API” will point to an API endpoint.
If your data has earlier versions available, there is a “temporal” field in the distribution section of the data.json file which will indicate the time period. An example is below.
data_json_url <- "https://data.cms.gov/data.json"
dataset_title <- "Medicare Inpatient Hospitals - by Provider and Service"
time_period   <- "2017-01-01/2017-12-31"

data_json_meta <- read_json_arrow(
  file = data_json_url,
  col_select = c("dataset"),
    as_data_frame = TRUE)

meta <- to_duckdb(data_json_meta) |> 
  pull(dataset) |> 
  pluck(1)
  
meta |> 
  dplyr::filter(grepl(dataset_title, title)) |> 
  dplyr::glimpse()
